collection1.Title: Obama Removes Weapons Freeze Against Egypt
collection1.Caption: President Obama has assured Egypt that he will support the $1.3 billion in annual military assistance the country usually receives.

First paragraph.text: WASHINGTON — Seeking to repair relations with a longtime ally at a time of spreading war in the Middle East, President Obama on Tuesday lifted an arms freeze against Egypt that he had first imposed after the military overthrow of the country’s democratically elected government nearly two years ago.

collection1.Title: Bills on ‘Religious Freedom’ Upset Capitols in Arkansas and Indiana
collection1.Caption: Protesters at the Arkansas Capitol on Tuesday rallied against a religious freedom bill that critics say could cause discrimination.

collection1.Title: Indiana Governor, Feeling Backlash From Law’s Opponents, Promises a ‘Fix’
collection1.Caption: Gov. Mike Pence speaking on Tuesday in Indianapolis about a new state law that opponents say legalizes discrimination against gays and lesbians. He said the reaction took him by surprise.

collection1.Title: Gary Dahl, Inventor of the Pet Rock, Dies at 78
collection1.Caption: Gary Dahl in 1975 with the Pet Rock, a product that sold for $3.95 and made him a millionaire practically overnight.
collection1.First paragraph: It was a craze to rival the Hula-Hoop, and even less explicable. For a mere three dollars and 95 cents, a consumer could buy ... a rock — a plain, ordinary, egg-shaped rock of the kind one could dig up in almost any backyard.

collection1.Title: Latest News: ‘Religious Freedom’ Bills, Andrew Getty, Tikrit Victory
collection1.Caption: Muhammadu Buhari, Nigeria's former military ruler, was elected its new president.

collection1.Title: Arkansas Governor’s Son Thrust Into Spotlight Over Religious Exception Bill
collection1.Caption: Seth Hutchinson, a son of Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas, is a union organizer.
collection1.First paragraph: When Gov. Asa Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, spoke on Wednesday about the future of what proponents call the religious freedom bill pending in his state, he disclosed that the proposal had drawn resistance from a particularly noteworthy critic: his son, Seth Hutchinson.

collection1.Title: Lufthansa Faces Mounting Challenges as More Details of Germanwings Crash Emerge
collection1.Caption: The airline executives Carsten Spohr, left, and Thomas Winkelmann at a plane crash memorial in Seyne-les-Alpes, France.

First paragraph.text: FRANKFURT — Lufthansa was supposed to be celebrating the 60th anniversary of its postwar rebirth this month.

collection1.Title: Atlanta Educators Convicted in School Cheating Scandal
collection1.Caption: Donald Bullock, a former Atlanta testing coordinator, was led to a holding cell after his conviction. A judge ordered most of the educators jailed immediately.
collection1.First paragraph: ATLANTA — In a dramatic conclusion to what has been described as the largest cheating scandal in the nation’s history, a jury here on Wednesday convicted 11 educators for their roles in a standardized test cheating scandal that tarnished a major school district’s reputation and raised broader questions about the role of high-stakes testing in American schools.

collection1.Title: California Imposes First Mandatory Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought
collection1.Caption: Houseboats float in California’s drought-lowered Oroville Lake.

collection1.Title: Former I.R.S. Official Won’t Be Charged for Refusing to Testify
collection1.Caption: Lois Lerner in March 2014. Republicans had argued that she waived her right to not incriminate herself at hearings before a House committee.

First paragraph.text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors have concluded that Lois Lerner, a former Internal Revenue Service official, should not be charged for refusing to answer questions before a congressional committee about the agency’s improper treatment of conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

collection1.Title: Senator Menendez Pleads Not Guilty to Bribery Accusations
collection1.Caption: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, right, at the federal courthouse in Newark after his arraignment on bribery charges.
collection1.First paragraph: Joined by a mutual fondness for good cigars and a round of golf, they spent holidays together in the Dominican Republic, unwinding at a gated oceanfront resort where houses cost as much as $20 million.

collection1.Title: Two Women in Queens Are Charged With a Bomb Plot
collection1.Caption: The women charged lived in Jamaica, Queens: Noelle Velentzas lived in this house, on Inwood Street, and Asia Siddiqui lived on 84th Road.

collection1.Title: Muslims Projected to Outnumber Christians by 2100
collection1.Caption: An Islamic Society of Delaware service last year. A Pew Research Center study says religions will remain a vibrant force.
collection1.First paragraph: Christianity has long been the world’s largest religion by far, but the population of Muslims is growing so fast that they will match Christians by the year 2070 and outnumber them by the end of the century, according to a report released Thursday that projects the global religious future.

collection1.Title: Californians Who Conserved Wonder if State Can Overcome Those Who Didn’t
collection1.Caption: Some Californians have cut down on watering their lawns, and others have decided to forgo greenery for native plants.
collection1.First paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Some Californians are already showering just once a week, with buckets at their feet to catch every errant drop. They are building rainwater tanks in their backyards and replacing their lawns with mesquite and desert sage. They glare at water-wasting neighbors, and post photographs online to “drought shame” businesses that spray down their sidewalks.

collection1.Title: Come Out and Live, Shabab Told Kenya Students. It Was a Lie.
collection1.Caption: A Kenyan forensics expert on Friday surveyed the damage to Garissa University College, where gunmen killed nearly 150 people.
collection1.First paragraph: GARISSA, Kenya — Elosy Karimi curled up in a crawl space, immobilized by fear.

collection1.Title: Kenyans Identify and Mourn Relatives Killed in Attack on University
collection1.Caption: A Salvation Army officer prayed on Saturday for relatives of those killed in Thursday’s attack at Garissa University College.

collection1.Title: Fidel Castro Appears in Public for First Time in 14 Months
collection1.Caption: Former President Fidel Castro of Cuba greeted a group of Venezuelan visitors as they toured a Havana school last week.

First paragraph.text: MEXICO CITY — Former President Fidel Castro of Cuba made a surprise appearance in public for the first time in 14 months, greeting a group of Venezuelan visitors as they toured a Havana school, the Cuban news media reported on Friday.

collection1.Title: Robert Burns Jr., First Lynyrd Skynyrd Drummer, Dies at 64
collection1.Caption: Robert Burns Jr. played drums in Lynyrd Skynyrd for 10 years.
collection1.First paragraph: Robert Burns Jr., the founding drummer of Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Southern rock band known for the power ballad “Free Bird” and the anthem “Sweet Home Alabama,” died on Friday in an automobile crash in Georgia. He was 64.

collection1.Title: As Serena Williams Ascends, Grand Slam Buzz Grows
collection1.Caption: Serena Williams captured her eighth Miami Open singles title with a 6-2, 6-0 rout of 12th-seeded Carla Suárez Navarro on Saturday.

First paragraph.text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — The women’s final between Serena Williams and Carla Suárez Navarro on Saturday at the Miami Open was predictably brutal and mercifully brief.

collection1.Title: Wisconsin Ends Kentucky’s Undefeated Streak and Will Face Duke for N.C.A.A. Title
collection1.Caption: Frank Kaminsky of Wisconsin shooting against Willie Cauley-Stein during the second half. Kaminsky had 20 points and 11 rebounds for the Badgers.
collection1.First paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — It was here, finally, after 364 days — long enough for Kentucky to reload and to rewrite history and for Wisconsin to reconcile its paralyzing defeat on this stage a year ago, or at least come close.

collection1.Title: G.O.P.’s Israel Support Deepens as Political Contributions Shift
collection1.Caption: Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, left, a leading critic of negotiations with Iran, has drawn support from pro-Israel donors.

collection1.Title: Kenyan Authorities Say Son of Official Was Among Gunmen in University Attack
collection1.Caption: Kenyans prayed during an Easter service on Sunday in Garissa, the town where Somali militants burst into a university on Thursday and killed nearly 150 students.
collection1.First paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — One of the gunmen who attacked the Kenyan university where nearly 150 students were massacred last week was the son of a government official — and once a promising student himself — who had recently broken off contact with his family and disappeared, the Kenyan authorities said Sunday.

collection1.Title: Rolling Stone Article on Rape at University of Virginia Failed All Basics, Report Says
collection1.Caption: The police in Charlottesville, Va., said last month they had found “no substantive basis” to support the article’s depiction of sexual assault at a fraternity at the University of Virginia above.

First paragraph.text: Rolling Stone magazine retracted its article about a brutal gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity after the release of a report on Sunday that concluded the widely discredited piece was the result of failures at every stage of the process.

collection1.Title: Notre Dame Stifles South Carolina’s Gritty Rally to Reach Second Straight Final
collection1.Caption: Notre Dame's Jewell Loyd shooting against South Carolina's Alaina Coates during the first half.

First paragraph.text: TAMPA, Fla. — South Carolina, which entered Sunday’s national semifinals with the 11th-ranked scoring defense in Division I, forced Notre Dame to play in the mud, slowing the game with gritty defense and stifling ball pressure.

collection1.Title: Beneath California Crops, Groundwater Crisis Grows
collection1.Caption: A well-drilling rig at an almond orchard in Hanford, Calif. Land devoted to water-thirsty almonds has doubled in the state in 20 years.

First paragraph.text: Even as the worst drought in decades ravages California, and its cities face mandatory cuts in water use, millions of pounds of thirsty crops like oranges, tomatoes and almonds continue to stream out of the state and onto the nation’s grocery shelves.

collection1.Title: Paul George’s Long-Awaited Return Electrifies Pacers’ Push
collection1.Caption: Indiana’s Paul George returned Sunday after breaking his right leg in August. “I think about it each step I take,” he said.

First paragraph.text: INDIANAPOLIS — With 6 minutes 7 seconds remaining in the first quarter of the Indiana Pacers’ game against Miami on Sunday, Coach Frank Vogel looked down his bench and said only one word: “Paul.”

collection1.Title: UConn Too Big, Too Savvy and Too Much for Upstart Maryland
collection1.Caption: Connecticut's Morgan Tuck shooting against Maryland's Shatori Walker-Kimbrough in the first half.
collection1.First paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — If there was one sequence of athletic precision that best illustrated the often cruel challenge of dealing with the Connecticut women’s basketball team, it came early in the second half of its national semifinal against Maryland on Sunday night.

collection1.Title: Boston Marathon Bombing Trial Wraps Up With Clashing Portraits of Naïveté and Extremism
collection1.Caption: From left, Judy Clarke, Miriam Conrad and David Bruck, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's lawyers, arrived for closing arguments in his trial Monday in Boston.
collection1.First paragraph: BOSTON — The courtroom filled with a swelling chorus of Islamic chants as television screens showed the battlefield carnage on Boylston Street, with severed limbs, an 11-year-old boy with bone fragments from someone else lodged in his body, and bright red blood splashed on the pavement like so many buckets of paint.

collection1.Title: Latest News: Rolling Stone Article, Iran Deal, Yemen Crisis
collection1.Caption: Rolling Stone has retracted an article on an alleged gang rape at the University of Virginia that led to an uproar.
collection1.First paragraph: Good morning.

collection1.Title: Skeptical of Iran Nuclear Deal, Israel Calls for Changes
collection1.Caption: Yuval Steinitz, Israel’s minister of intelligence and strategic affairs, in Paris last month.

First paragraph.text: JERUSALEM — Clearly unsatisfied with assurances from President Obama about the provisions of the Iran nuclear deal, Israel on Monday listed specific requirements that it declared were necessary in any final agreement.

collection1.Title: Ron Paul Is Expected to Play Little Role in Rand Paul’s Campaign
collection1.Caption: Ron Paul with his son Rand Paul at an event in New Hampshire in 2012. Ron Paul has “his own stuff going on," said Jesse Benton, a member of the Paul family, "and he’s not at the beck and call of anyone’s campaign — even his son’s.”
collection1.First paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — He was one of the most energizing forces in the Republican primaries in 2008 and 2012, an improbable hero whose speeches drew libertarians and college students by the hundreds and sometimes thousands.

collection1.Title: Shabab Militants Learning to Kill on a Shoestring
collection1.Caption: Ethiopian troops as part of an international force in Somalia fighting the Shabab.
collection1.First paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — They have lost their leader, their ports, their checkpoints and their territory.

collection1.Title: University of Virginia Fraternity to Go After Rolling Stone for Rape Article
collection1.Caption: The Phi Kappa Psi fraternity house in Charlottesville, Va.

First paragraph.text: The University of Virginia fraternity at the center of a retracted article by Rolling Stone magazine that detailed a purported gang rape by its members said on Monday that it planned “to pursue all available legal action against the magazine.”

collection1.Title: Crisis in Palestinian Camp in Syria Has Worsened Since ISIS Invasion, U.N. Says
collection1.Caption: A man climbed a staircase inside a demolished building in the Yarmouk refugee camp near the Syrian capital of Damascus on Monday.

First paragraph.text: UNITED NATIONS — Relief officials at the United Nations expressed alarm on Monday about a deepening humanitarian disaster in Syria’s Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp, which was invaded last week by Islamic State militants and their allies.

collection1.Title: Latest News: ISIS Violence, Chicago Mayor, Rand Paul
collection1.Caption: Duke defeated Wisconsin, 68-63, Monday night in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship. It is Duke's fifth title.

collection1.Title: It Went Back and Forth, Until Duke Stood Tallest
collection1.Caption: Jahlil Okafor and Tyus Jones after Duke’s 68-63 victory over Wisconsin on Monday night.

collection1.Title: Rand Paul’s Challenge: Libertarians Are Still a Small Minority

First paragraph.text: It has become fashionable in recent years to refer to a growing libertarian wing of the Republican Party, and Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator who announced his candidacy for the presidency on Tuesday, hopes to become the first serious candidate to make it part of a winning primary coalition.

collection1.Title: A Duke Title, Just as Tyus Jones and Fellow Freshmen Planned It Long Ago
collection1.Caption: Tyus Jones on Monday night. He scored 23 points, with five rebounds and only one turnover, in 37 minutes.

collection1.Title: Iran’s Leaders Fall Into Line Behind Nuclear Accord
collection1.Caption: A mural in Tehran depicting the Islamic Republic's founder, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, right; the Basij paramilitary force; and Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
collection1.First paragraph: TEHRAN — Since the Islamic Revolution in 1979, Iranian hard-liners have been free to take to the streets and object to any form of compromise with the West, and particularly the United States.

collection1.Title: After Victory Over ISIS in Tikrit, Next Battle Requires a New Template
collection1.Caption: Iraqi forces in Tikrit after Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the city had been reclaimed from the Islamic State. Anbar Province is the focus now.

First paragraph.text: Emboldened as they mop up the last Islamic State forces in the city of Tikrit, Iraqi military leaders are already vowing to follow up that operation with a much more ambitious one: marching into the vast Sunni heartland in western Iraq to root out some of the most significant militant strongholds.

collection1.Title: After Victory Over ISIS in Tikrit, Next Battle Requires a New Template
collection1.Caption: Iraqi forces in Tikrit after Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the city had been reclaimed from the Islamic State. Anbar Province is the focus now.

collection1.Title: Stan Freberg, Madcap Adman and Satirist, Dies at 88
collection1.Caption: Stan Freberg in 1983.
collection1.First paragraph: Stan Freberg, a humorist whose sprawling imagination fueled a multifaceted career that included pretty much inventing the idea of using satire in commercials, died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 88.

collection1.Title: Rahm Emanuel Wins Runoff Election to Secure 2nd Term as Chicago Mayor
collection1.Caption: Rahm Emanuel before giving his victory speech after being re-elected mayor of Chicago in a runoff election on Tuesday.

collection1.Title: UConn’s Win Isn’t Pretty, but Title Is a Perfect 10th for Geno Auriemma
collection1.Caption: Notre Dame’s Taya Reimer fighting for a rebound with Connecticut’s Kia Nurse, center, and Breanna Stewart, who was named the most outstanding player of the Final Four.
collection1.First paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Connecticut’s third straight N.C.A.A. women’s basketball championship was impassioned, not pretty. But in the end, it was perfect.

collection1.Title: Ferguson Elects 2 Blacks to City Council, but Rejects Activist Candidates
collection1.Caption: Turnout was just under 30 percent, still far shy of presidential races but nearly three times the turnout for the last Council election, two years ago.

collection1.Title: Royal Dutch Shell to Buy BG Group for Nearly $70 Billion
collection1.Caption: A Royal Dutch Shell plant in Torzhok, Russia. Shell has offered to pay a 50 percent premium for BG Group.

collection1.Title: Chicago Is Waiting to See if Runoff Battle Has Humbled Rahm Emanuel
collection1.Caption: Mayor Rahm Emanuel with his daughters at a rally on Tuesday night in Chicago. He thanked the voters for “putting me through my paces.”

First paragraph.text: CHICAGO — By some measure, everything ended just as it had begun. After an unexpected and unprecedented runoff election in the nation’s third-largest city, Chicago’s brash mayor, Rahm Emanuel, was still Chicago’s mayor.

collection1.Title: Latest News: South Carolina Shooting, Yemen Crisis, Ferguson Election
collection1.Caption: Video shows a police officer in North Charleston, S.C., shooting an apparently unarmed man after a scuffle at a traffic stop.
collection1.First paragraph: Good morning.

collection1.Title: Palestinian Stabs 2 Israeli Soldiers and Is Killed
collection1.Caption: Israeli security forces removed the body of a Palestinian man who attacked two soldiers on Wednesday, near Sinjil, West Bank. The man was shot to death by security forces at the scene.

collection1.Title: Officer Who Killed Walter Scott Is Fired, and Police Chief Denounces Shooting
collection1.Caption: Demonstrators gathered outside of North Charleston City Hall on Wednesday morning to share their accounts of what they said was systemic racism.
collection1.First paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — The police officer who was arrested on Tuesday after shooting and killing an unarmed black man has been fired from the department and the police chief here said Wednesday that he was appalled by what a video of the encounter revealed.

collection1.Title: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Is Guilty on All 30 Counts in Boston Marathon Bombing
collection1.Caption: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, second from left, flanked by his defense lawyers, showed no emotion Wednesday as a clerk delivered the jury’s guilty verdict in the Boston Marathon bombing trial.
collection1.First paragraph: BOSTON — In the silent well of Courtroom Nine, a clerk read out the jury’s verdicts: Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. The word echoed in the courtroom as the clerk pronounced it 30 times, once for each of 30 main counts.

collection1.Title: Rand Paul Gets the TV Spotlight and Turns It on Interviewers in Testy Encounters
collection1.Caption: Senator Rand Paul, left, Republican of Kentucky, in the Milford, N.H., Town Hall, where he held a campaign event Wednesday.

First paragraph.text: NASHUA, N.H. — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky is spending the week trying to introduce himself to Americans as the sensitive, softer-edged face of the Republican Party. He talks about how helping his grandmother as she lost her sight inspired him to become an eye surgeon — and how on a volunteer mission in Guatemala, he enabled a husband and wife to see each other clearly for the first time in years.

collection1.Title: HBO Now Makes ‘Game of Thrones’ Easier to See, if Not Follow
collection1.Caption: HBO has released an app, HBO Now, for streaming its programs with no cable subscription required.
collection1.First paragraph: THE popular television show “Game of Thrones” has become harder to follow, with all the characters that come and go. But it has also become much easier to watch online.

collection1.Title: Review: Vanessa Hudgens in a Squeaky Clean ‘Gigi’ on Broadway
collection1.Caption: Gigi Corey Cott as Gaston and Vanessa Hudgens as Gigi in the revival of this Lerner and Loewe musical, set in belle époque Paris, at the Neil Simon Theater.

First paragraph.text: A shower of soap bubbles descends upon the audience at the finale of the pretty and pleasant revival of the musical “Gigi” that opened at the Neil Simon Theater on Wednesday. The gentle downpour is meant to evoke the fizz in a glass of Champagne, the delights of which have been celebrated in one of the bounciest songs from the score by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe.

collection1.Title: Veteran CBS Newscaster Bob Schieffer Announces Plan to Retire
collection1.Caption: Bob Schieffer in 2012. The 78-year-old newsman, who has worked at CBS for nearly half a century, hosts the Sunday morning program “Face the Nation.”

collection1.Title: Obama Calls for End to ‘Conversion’ Therapies for Gay and Transgender Youth
collection1.Caption: President Obama before boarding Marine One on Tuesday at the White House.
collection1.First paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 17-year-old transgender youth, Leelah Alcorn, stunned her friends and a vast Internet audience in December when she threw herself in front of a tractor-trailer after writing in an online suicide note that religious therapists had tried to convert her back to being a boy.

collection1.Title: Piling Sand in a Disputed Sea, China Literally Gains Ground
collection1.Caption: A satellite image from March 16 shows work on an emerging artificial island at Mischief Reef in the South China Sea.
collection1.First paragraph: WASHINGTON — The clusters of Chinese vessels busily dredge white sand and pump it onto partly submerged coral, aptly named Mischief Reef, transforming it into an island.

collection1.Title: Listeria in Sabra Hummus Prompts New Wave of Recalls
collection1.Caption: Sabra Dipping Company recalled 30,000 cases of its classic hummus after tubs in Michigan tested positive for listeria.
collection1.First paragraph: Two food manufacturers have issued nationwide recalls of products because of the discovery of the potentially lethal bacterium listeria, which federal authorities have now linked to three deaths and five illnesses in Texas and Kansas.

collection1.Title: California Orders Utility to Pay $1.6 Billion in Fatal Natural Gas Fire
collection1.Caption: A Pacific Gas and Electric pipeline explosion in 2010 destroyed dozens of homes in San Bruno, near San Francisco. The penalty is the largest ever imposed by the state’s utilities commission.

First paragraph.text: SAN FRANCISCO — California’s chief utility regulator on Thursday ordered Pacific Gas and Electric, the state’s largest power utility, to pay $1.6 billion in fines and other penalties stemming from a deadly natural gas pipeline rupture and fire near San Francisco in 2010.

collection1.Title: South Carolina Police Shooting Seen as Crime Strategy Gone Awry
collection1.Caption: Rashard Brown, 30, complained that the police in North Charleston, S.C., had pulled him over twice in two months.
collection1.First paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — It was after dark about five years ago, on a downtrodden strip of this city, when Alicia Delesline stopped trusting the police in the place where she had lived her entire life.

collection1.Title: On a Day for Good Scores at the Masters, Jordan Spieth Has a Great One
collection1.Caption: Jordan Spieth teeing off on the 13th hole at Augusta on Thursday.

collection1.Title: Schumer Is Squeezed on Various Sides Over Iran Deal
collection1.Caption: Senator Charles E. Schumer supports a bill that would ensure the right of Congress to essentially approve or disapprove the rollback of sanctions against Iran, which could disrupt a nuclear deal.

collection1.Title: Pakistani Lawmakers Urge Diplomacy in Yemen Conflict but Decline Combat Role
collection1.Caption: Soldiers guarding the Parliament building in Islamabad, Pakistan, on Friday, when lawmakers unanimously passed a resolution on Yemen.

First paragraph.text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Parliament voted on Friday to stay out of the conflict in Yemen, but it urged the government led by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to play a diplomatic role in defusing the crisis.

collection1.Title: Hillary Clinton to Announce 2016 Run for President on Sunday
collection1.Caption: Hillary Clinton is expected to begin her 2016 campaign for president with a video message on  Sunday.

First paragraph.text: The prolonged prologue to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s second run for the White House will reach its suspenseless conclusion on Sunday: The former secretary of state, senator and first lady is to announce that she will indeed seek the Democratic nomination for president.

collection1.Title: Lauren Hill, Who Fought Tumor to Play College Basketball, Dies at 19
collection1.Caption: Lauren Hill of Mount St. Joseph in her first college game, during which she scored with her nondominant hand.
collection1.First paragraph: Lauren Hill, who played basketball for Mount St. Joseph University in Cincinnati while contending with an inoperable brain tumor, died on Friday in Cincinnati. She was 19.

collection1.Title: G.E. Is Finally Exorcising Financial Demons From Jack Welch Era
collection1.Caption: Jack Welch was chairman and chief executive of General Electric from 1981 to 2001.

First paragraph.text: At long last, General Electric is on its way to exorcising the financial demons of Jack Welch.

collection1.Title: The Best Reason to Take Rand Paul Seriously Has Nothing to Do With His Politics
collection1.Caption: Senator Rand Paul announcing his bid for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday in Louisville, Ky.

collection1.Title: Jordan Spieth Breaks 36-Hole Record at Masters and Then Shrugs
collection1.Caption: Jordan Spieth after finishing the second round at 14 under.
collection1.First paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — On Thursday, when Jordan Spieth shot a 64 and nearly set the record for the lowest 18-hole score at the Masters, the soft-spoken Spieth conceded he might have taken advantage of favorable conditions and a few lucky breaks.

collection1.Title: Review: ‘Clinton the Musical’ Proves Unimpeachably Amusing
collection1.Caption: "Clinton the Musical," with Duke Lafoon and Veronica J. Kuehn, at New World Stages.

First paragraph.text: First came the gnashing of teeth over Hillary Clinton’s private email account, and her soon-to-be announced presidential campaign. Then, with a TED talk, Monica Lewinsky signaled her return to the spotlight. Now a show called “Clinton the Musical” has opened Off Broadway.

collection1.Title: Yemen’s Despair on Full Display in ‘Ruined’ City
collection1.Caption: Yemeni supporters of a southern separatist movement fought with Houthi rebels in an Aden neighborhood on Wednesday.
collection1.First paragraph: ADEN, Yemen — Rooftop snipers have emptied the streets of this dusty seaside city and swelled its hospitals and morgues.

collection1.Title: North Charleston Prepares for Mourning and Protest in Walter Scott Shooting
collection1.Caption: Mourners on Friday afternoon at the Charleston, S.C., funeral home where a viewing was held for Walter L. Scott, who was killed a week ago as he ran away from a police officer.
collection1.First paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — In a ritual that has been repeated around the country after racially charged police killings, this working-class city was preparing Friday for a weekend of public mourning and angry protest over the death of an unarmed black man who was shot in the back by a white police officer.

collection1.Title: After Seven Hours and 19 Innings, One Hit Sinks the Yankees
collection1.Caption: Xander Bogaerts of the Boston Red Sox scored in the 19th inning.

First paragraph.text: When it was over, when the Boston Red Sox had deftly turned a double play to end a game that had begun more than seven hours earlier, Yankee Stadium was empty enough to hear their celebratory shouts as players and coaches emptied out of the dugout.

collection1.Title: American Among Nearly 40 Sentenced to Life in Prison for Egypt Protests
collection1.Caption: Egyptian policemen guarded the defendants’ cage in a Cairo courtroom on Saturday at a verdict hearing for nearly 40 people in an antigovernment protest case.

First paragraph.text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Saturday sentenced an American citizen, Mohamed Soltan, to life imprisonment for supporting an Islamist protest against the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood in the summer of 2013.

collection1.Title: Günter Grass Dies at 87; Writer Pried Open Germany’s Past but Hid His Own
collection1.Caption: Günter Grass in 2005. The publication in 1959 of the “The Tin Drum” propelled him to the forefront of postwar literature.

First paragraph.text: Günter Grass, the German novelist, social critic and Nobel Prize winner whom many called his country’s moral conscience but who stunned Europe when he revealed in 2006 that he had been a member of the Waffen-SS during World War II, died on Monday in the northern German city of Lübeck, which had been his home for decades. He was 87.

collection1.Title: Cuba to Be Removed From U.S. List of Nations That Sponsor Terrorism
collection1.Caption: A Havana street in late December. In Cuba, the label of state sponsor of terrorism is blamed for discouraging financial institutions from working with the country.

First paragraph.text: The White House announced on Tuesday that President Obama intends to remove Cuba from the American government’s list of nations that sponsor terrorism, eliminating a major obstacle to the restoration of diplomatic relations after decades of hostilities.

collection1.Title: As Cuba Opens Up, Fashion Reacts
collection1.Caption: Cuba has always occupied an outsize space in designers' imagination. Donatella Versace’s spring/summer 2015 men’s collection, for example, used white jeans embroidered in gold palm leaves, sorbet shades of pink and sand and ocean blue, and lacelike inserts that made references to Havana architecture.
collection1.First paragraph: When people talk about the resumption of relations between the United States and Cuba, as they did over the weekend as President Obama and President Raúl Castro sat down for the first meeting between leaders of their two countries in more than 50 years, they talk mostly about history and diplomacy and influence, and what it could mean for the future in terms of trade and travel, not to mention human rights.

collection1.Title: Aaron Hernandez Found Guilty of First-Degree Murder
collection1.Caption: The former New England Patriots player Aaron Hernandez during his murder trial on Wednesday.

First paragraph.text: Aaron Hernandez, a former tight end with the New England Patriots, was convicted of first-degree murder and several weapons and ammunitions charges Wednesday, ending the stunning downfall of a player who was once one of the N.F.L.’s most promising young stars.

collection1.Title: Iran Assails U.S. Plan for a Vote in Congress
collection1.Caption: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran in the northern city of Rasht on Wednesday.

First paragraph.text: TEHRAN — Iran’s president on Wednesday dismissed the compromise worked out between the Obama administration and Congress over an impending nuclear agreement as internal American politics, saying the Iranians were negotiating with six countries, not just with the United States.

collection1.Title: Google Joins Its U.S. Peers Under Europe’s Scrutiny

First paragraph.text: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last few decades, Europe’s regulators have challenged the practices of some of the titans of American technology, including Microsoft, Intel and now Google.

collection1.Title: Tensions Flare Between Iraq and Saudi Arabia in U.S. Coalition
collection1.Caption: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq, center, on Capitol Hill on Wednesday. He is making his first official visit to Washington.

First paragraph.text: WASHINGTON — A remarkable clash between two key American allies in the Middle East burst into the open here on Wednesday as the Iraqi prime minister publicly criticized the Saudi air campaign in Yemen and a top Saudi official retorted that there was “no logic to those remarks.”

collection1.Title: Aaron Hernandez Shed Tackles, but Not His Past
collection1.Caption: The former Patriot Aaron Hernandez, 25, was handcuffed after he was convicted of killing Odin Lloyd, whose body was found in 2013.
collection1.First paragraph: Aaron Hernandez grew up in the flagging factory city of Bristol, Conn., where during his youth a declining downtown was prowled by petty criminals who dreamed of making bigger scores in New England’s prosperous hubs.

collection1.Title: In Test for Unions and Politicians, a Nationwide Protest on Pay
collection1.Caption: Protesters at a McDonald’s in Brooklyn on Wednesday demanded a $15 minimum wage.
collection1.First paragraph: The protest by tens of thousands of low-wage workers, students and activists in more than 200 American cities on Wednesday is the most striking effort to date in a two-and-a-half-year-old labor-backed movement that is testing the ability of unions to succeed in an economy populated by easily replaceable service sector workers.

collection1.Title: Pilot of Gyrocopter Is Arrested After Landing on Lawn at Capitol
collection1.Caption: A small gyrocopter sat on the West Lawn of the Capitol, where it had landed, in Washington on Wednesday.

collection1.Title: Use of E-Cigarettes Rises Sharply Among Teenagers, Report Says
collection1.Caption: Customers at Beyond Vape, an e-cigarette and e-liquid store in Manhattan.

collection1.Title: Mix of Curiosity and Outrage on the Hill After Pilot Buzzes Capitol
collection1.Caption: Doug Hughes, 61, aloft last month. He was charged on Thursday for landing his lightweight gyrocopter on Capitol Hill.
collection1.First paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some prominent lawmakers raised questions on Thursday about how the pilot of a gyrocopter, eager to deliver a protest message to Congress over campaign finance laws, was able to fly the aircraft apparently undetected through protected airspace and land near the Capitol.

collection1.Title: For Lucasfilm, the Way of Its Force Lies in Its ‘Star Wars’ Fans
Bloomberg Terminals Suffer Widespread Failures
collection1.Caption: Bloomberg’s data terminals are the company’s signature product, connecting trading floors with a chat function and providing market data and news.
collection1.First paragraph: The web that weaves together much of the global financial ecosystem went down for a few hours on Friday when the Bloomberg data and communication network unexpectedly crashed.

collection1.Title: General Electric Reports Strong Growth in Industrial Businesses
collection1.Caption: Production engines at a G.E. plant in Ohio. Its aviation, power-generation and transportation units generated solid growth.

collection1.Title: South Africa Moves to Quell Anti-Immigrant Violence
collection1.Caption: Zulu men confronted foreigners on Friday in the Johannesburg city center. Some impoverished South Africans accuse foreigners of stealing jobs.

collection1.Title: At Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Ceremony, a Generational Push and Pull
collection1.Caption: Miley Cyrus and Joan Jett at the Rock and Roll Hall  of Fame induction ceremony.
collection1.First paragraph: CLEVELAND — Although the show went on for five hours, a few things managed to go unmentioned at the 30th annual Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony on Saturday night here. Among the relevant topics not discussed: the solo catalog of Ringo Starr, who became the fourth and final Beatle to gain entry to the Hall twice over, this time as an individual; disco, rap and dance music, some of the rock-adjacent genres not represented in this year’s class; and the conspicuous decades-long absence of Bill Withers, one of the show’s honorees, from the music industry.

collection1.Title: Hundreds of Migrants Are Feared Dead as Ship Capsizes Off Libyan Coast
collection1.Caption: A video still shows an Italian Coast Guard vessel during a search-and-rescue operation in the Mediterranean Sea on Sunday.

collection1.Title: Trial Postponed for Greek Neo-Fascist Golden Dawn Party Members
collection1.Caption: Giorgos Roupakias, a supporter of the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party who has admitted to killing a leftist rapper, Pavlos Fyssas, was led Monday into a courtroom in a prison west of Athens.

First paragraph.text: KORYDALLOS, Greece — In the highest-profile political trial in Greece in decades, members of the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party appeared in court on Monday for a brief hearing as their trial was scheduled to open on charges including membership in a criminal organization and murder.

collection1.Title: This Time, Lelisa Desisa Wins Boston Marathon for Himself
collection1.Caption: Lelisa Desisa crossing the finish line. As he rounded Hereford Street for the sprint to the finish, he cast off his hat in triumph and waved to the crowd.

First paragraph.text: BOSTON — Two hours after Lelisa Desisa won the Boston Marathon in 2013, two bombs ripped through the finish area, killing three spectators and wounding 264 others.

collection1.Title: Charges Against Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter Held in Iran, Include Espionage
collection1.Caption: Jason Rezaian in 2013.

First paragraph.text: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent incarcerated in Iran for nine months, has been charged with four serious crimes including espionage, his Iranian lawyer said on Monday. The newspaper and the White House denounced the charges, calling them absurd.

collection1.Title: Baltimore Suspends 6 Police Officers in Inquiry in Death of Freddie Gray
collection1.Caption: Protesters on Monday in Baltimore after the death of a man who had been tackled by the police.
collection1.First paragraph: BALTIMORE — Six police officers have been suspended and officials said Monday that they were changing police procedures as they investigated the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who was rushed to the hospital with a severed spinal cord after being chased and tackled by officers.

collection1.Title: At Least 25 Die as Airstrike Sets Off Huge Blast in Yemen
collection1.Caption: A Yemeni man checked a house in Sana after a bombing that killed at least 25 people. Sana has been bombed almost daily for more than three weeks, damaging factories, gas stations and residential neighborhoods.

First paragraph.text: SANA, Yemen — An airstrike apparently carried out by the Saudi-led military coalition set off a huge explosion on Monday morning in Sana, the capital of Yemen, flattening homes close to the site and shaking buildings as far away as the outskirts of the city. At least 25 people were killed, according to witnesses and medical officials.

collection1.Title: Rangers Stifle Penguins for 40 Minutes, Then Withstand a Flurry
collection1.Caption: Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist making one of his 23 saves. The Rangers held the Penguins to 11 shots on goal through two periods.
collection1.First paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The Rangers put an eye-opening 20-minute hiccup from Saturday behind them and regained their defensive consciousness Monday.

collection1.Title: New Genetic Tests for Breast Cancer Hold Promise
collection1.Caption: Mary-Claire King, a geneticist whose work led to the discovery of a gene that carries an added risk for breast cancer, has called for testing to be offered to all American women 30 and older.

First paragraph.text: A Silicon Valley start-up with some big-name backers is threatening to upend genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer by offering a test on a sample of saliva that is so inexpensive that most women could get it.

collection1.Title: Campaign Casts Hillary Clinton as the Populist It Insists She Has Always Been
collection1.Caption: Hillary Rodham Clinton met with members of the public after a round-table discussion in Concord, N.H., on Tuesday.

First paragraph.text: CLAREMONT, N.H. — In her first week as a 2016 presidential candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton seemed to channel another high-profile Democrat. “The deck is stacked in their favor,” Mrs. Clinton said of the wealthy and powerful. “My job is to reshuffle the cards.”

collection1.Title: Penalty Phase Opens With Image of Boston Marathon Bomber Making Obscene Gesture
collection1.Caption: Demonstrators against capital punishment outside federal court in Boston on Tuesday, the first day of the penalty phase in the marathon bombing trial.

collection1.Title: Super PACs Are Gobbling Up Even More Power, Jeb Bush Edition

First paragraph.text: The super PAC, which transformed the 2012 presidential election as a new conduit of influence for wealthy donors, is gaining even more power and flexibility for the 2016 elections.

collection1.Title: For Blue Bell, a Drastic Move to Recall Ice Cream as Listeria Findings Rose
collection1.Caption: Blue Bell Creameries products have been removed from shelves in more than 20 states, including at this Kansas store.
collection1.First paragraph: The alert hit HEB Grocery in San Antonio late Monday: Blue Bell Creameries, a Southwestern favorite and the country’s third-largest ice cream brand, was recalling all its frozen desserts over concerns of contamination by the potentially deadly bacteria listeria.

collection1.Title: Judge Orders Stony Brook University to Defend Its Custody of 2 Chimps
collection1.Caption: A retired lab chimpanzee at Chimp Haven, a sanctuary in Louisiana. An animal-rights group is currently seeking to have two chimps on Long Island sent to a sanctuary in Florida.
collection1.First paragraph: They may not know it, and they most certainly will not be in attendance, but Hercules and Leo will have their day in court.

collection1.Title: New Orleans Bars Issue Last Call for Smoking
collection1.Caption: Ben Sherman, pouring beer, urged his customers at the Kingpin to “go out in a blaze of glory” before a ban on smoking in New Orleans bars went into effect early Wednesday.
collection1.First paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — No one goes to a bar here, particularly one that advertises its hours as “2 p.m. till,” and expects precision about the time of day. But it was right on the stroke of midnight that Frankie Mazzanti, 56, one of the owners of the low-ceilinged neighborhood joint called 45 Tchoup, went along the bar picking up ashtrays and tossing them in a plastic bag.

collection1.Title: Taliban Are Said to Target Hazaras to Try to Match ISIS’ Brutality
collection1.Caption: Relatives of abducted members of Afghanistan's Hazara ethnic group and activists gathered throughout Kabul this week to protest what they call government inaction against persecution.

First paragraph.text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A wave of kidnappings followed by numerous beheadings of members of Afghanistan’s Hazara ethnic group have spread alarm and anger among a people who historically have been this country’s most persecuted.

collection1.Title: Pope Francis Plans to Visit Cuba This Year
collection1.Caption: Pope Francis in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City on Wednesday. Officials said he would go to Cuba before arriving in the United States, which he is expected to visit in September.

First paragraph.text: ROME — Pope Francis will visit Cuba later this year, stopping there on his way to the United States, the Vatican said on Wednesday.

collection1.Title: Google Introduces Wireless Service Called Project Fi
collection1.Caption: Google's new phone service, Project Fi, will be available only to people using Google’s Nexus 6 phone.

First paragraph.text: Now you can Google a phone call.

collection1.Title: Appeals Court Overturns Barry Bonds’s Only Conviction
collection1.Caption: Barry Bonds in 2011 after he was convicted of obstruction of justice. That conviction was overturned on Wednesday.

First paragraph.text: After years of investigations and court proceedings in the performance-enhancing drug case involving Barry Bonds, baseball’s home run king, federal prosecutors were able to pin only one obstruction of justice conviction on him.

collection1.Title: Hidden Armenians of Turkey Seek to Reclaim Their Erased Identities
collection1.Caption: A priest prepared to administer the Easter Mass at the Surp Giragos Church in Diyarbakir, Turkey. It is the largest Armenian church in Turkey and the Middle East.

collection1.Title: Deutsche Bank to Pay $2.5 Billion Fine to Settle Rate-Rigging Case
collection1.Caption: Deutsche Bank was part of an investigation in a case that spotlighted the collusive elements of Wall Street trading desks.
collection1.First paragraph: They called each other “dude,” “mate” and “amigo,” suggesting a certain innocence to their friendship. And yet at the center of their dispatches, United States and British authorities say, was actually a collusive effort to manipulate worldwide interest rates.

collection1.Title: Senate Confirms Loretta Lynch as Attorney General After Long Delay
collection1.Caption: Loretta E. Lynch testified at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on her nomination as attorney general in January.

collection1.Title: Adam Gadahn Was Propagandist for Al Qaeda Who Sold Terror in English
collection1.Caption: Adam Gadahn

First paragraph.text: WASHINGTON — If Osama bin Laden was the founding force behind Al Qaeda, then Adam Gadahn was perhaps its leading American voice.

collection1.Title: Latest News: Armenian Genocide, Drone Reprisals, Monty Python
collection1.Caption: A rally in Paris to commemorate the Armenian genocide that left up to 1.5 million people dead.
collection1.First paragraph: Good morning.

collection1.Title: Armenia, on Day of Rain and Sorrow, Observes 100th Anniversary of Genocide
collection1.Caption: The Tsitsernakaberd Memorial Complex, a monument to the roughly 1.5 million Armenians killed, during a commemoration ceremony Friday in Yerevan.

First paragraph.text: YEREVAN, Armenia — Thousands of Armenians laid flowers around an eternal flame here on Friday in memory of the 1.5 million people killed in Ottoman Turkey a century ago. The ceremony was one of many around the world marking the 100th anniversary of what historians call a genocide.

collection1.Title: Tyson to End Use of Human Antibiotics in Its Chickens by 2017
collection1.Caption: A truckload of chickens at a Tyson Foods plant in Springdale, Ark.

First paragraph.text: Tyson Foods, one of the country’s largest meat producers, said on Tuesday that it planned to eliminate the use of human antibiotics in its chicken production by 2017.

collection1.Title: Turmoil in Baltimore Provides Immediate Test for New Attorney General
collection1.Caption: Loretta E. Lynch was sworn in as attorney general on Monday hours before riots erupted in Baltimore.
collection1.First paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he prepared to swear in Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general on Monday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said she was uniquely qualified to bridge the divide between minority neighborhoods and police officers clashing over the use of deadly force.

collection1.Title: Excerpts From the Supreme CourtSame-Sex Marriage Arguments
Suzanne Crough, Actress in ‘The Partridge Family,’ Dies at 52
collection1.Caption: Suzanne Crough, who played Tracy, had appeared only in a Barbie commercial before she was cast on “The Partridge Family."
collection1.First paragraph: Suzanne Crough, who played the youngest daughter on “The Partridge Family,” the hit 1970s sitcom about a family band, died on Monday at her home in Laughlin, Nev. She was 52.

collection1.Title: 11th-Hour Deal Spared Philippine Woman From Indonesian Firing Squad
collection1.Caption: Indonesians gathered to pray for the condemned prisoners scheduled for a mass execution early Wednesday in Cilacap.

First paragraph.text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A last-ditch effort by the Philippines, involving a human trafficking case and frantic personal phone calls by the president, led to a dramatic deal with Indonesia that plucked a Philippine woman from a firing squad moments before she was to join eight other prisoners at a mass execution early Wednesday.

collection1.Title: Russian Space Station Cargo Ship Is Said to Be Out of Control
collection1.Caption: A Russian rocket carrying the Progress M-27M cargo ship was launched from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Tuesday.

First paragraph.text: MOSCOW — Russia’s top space officials announced Wednesday that they would scuttle an unmanned cargo spacecraft that is orbiting the Earth after it malfunctioned on its way to resupply the International Space Station.

collection1.Title: Orioles Play in Eerily Empty Stadium, Sirens in Distance

First paragraph.text: BALTIMORE — On what might have been a perfect spring afternoon to sit with a beer and a hot dog and watch baseball, an eerie emptiness greeted the Baltimore Orioles and the Chicago White Sox on Wednesday in what was believed to be the first major league game played without spectators.

collection1.Title: Over 140 Arrested as New Yorkers Protest the Death of Freddie Gray
collection1.Caption: Police officers arrested a protester on Wednesday near Union Square in Manhattan.

First paragraph.text: In an aggressive response designed to tamp down early signs of unrest, the police arrested 143 people in Manhattan on Wednesday night as protesters marched in a show of solidarity with demonstrators in Baltimore angered by the death of Freddie Gray, an unarmed 25-year-old black man who died after being injured while in police custody this month.

collection1.Title: This Ring Is Anything but Ornate, Yet All Eyes Will Be on It Anyway
collection1.Caption: Placing rope covers and other finishing touches on the ring at MGM Grand Garden Arena on Tuesday.

collection1.Title: Mayor de Blasio Defends Police Response to Freddie Gray Protests in New York
collection1.Caption: Demonstrators in Manhattan clashed with the police late on Wednesday.

First paragraph.text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, facing an uproar over arrests at a Manhattan rally to protest strong-armed policing, offered a spirited defense of law enforcement on Thursday, brushing off concerns that demonstrators had been mistreated even as he insisted on his own commitment to reform.

collection1.Title: 2 Indicted in George Washington Bridge Case; Ally of Christie Pleads Guilty
collection1.Caption: David Wildstein, right, leaving the federal courthouse in Newark on Friday after his guilty plea.

First paragraph.text: After a 16-month federal investigation into the George Washington Bridge lane closings scandal, a judge in New Jersey unsealed indictments against two people close to Gov. Chris Christie, outlining a conspiracy made with a third confidant to exact political vengeance against a mayor for not endorsing the governor’s re-election.

collection1.Title: Ben E. King, Soulful Singer of ‘Stand by Me,’ Dies at 76
collection1.Caption: Ben E. King performing in 1977.
collection1.First paragraph: Ben E. King, the smooth, soulful baritone who led the Drifters on “There Goes My Baby,” “Save the Last Dance for Me” and other hits in the late 1950s and early 1960s, and as a solo artist recorded the classic singles “Spanish Harlem” and “Stand by Me,” died on Thursday in Hackensack, N.J. He was 76.

collection1.Title: The Inevitable Spectacle of Mayweather vs. Pacquiao
collection1.Caption: Floyd Mayweather works with his trainer at Mayweather Boxing Club in Las Vegas.

First paragraph.text: Every once in a while, in these latter days since boxing receded from the cultural center, a fight temporarily reverses that history by catching the attention of the general public and becoming, as the TV announcers say, “bigger than boxing.” Then it’s not just that two boxers are going to fight. It’s more like two celebrities are going to fight — Drake vs. Lionel Messi, say, or Angelina Jolie vs. Angela Merkel — and we’re in luck because the celebrities in question happen to be atavistically good with their hands. Intimate familiarity with the craft of fist fighting has declined steeply in America and other rich countries since the mid-20th century, but what the spectacle of boxing has lost in daily resonance it has partly gained back in the form of esoteric old-school cachet.

collection1.Title: Women in Military Cite Retaliation After Assault Complaints
collection1.Caption: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, left, outlined on Friday the steps that the military was taking to reduce the thousands of sexual assaults that occur each year.
collection1.First paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly two-thirds of women in the military who filed sexual assault complaints last year said they faced retaliation, according to a Pentagon report released on Friday.

collection1.Title: U.S. Indictment Details Plotting in New Jersey Bridge Scandal
collection1.Caption: On Friday, Bridget Anne Kelly, who has proclaimed her innocence, suggested that sarcastic comments she made amid the George Washington Bridge lane closings had been taken too seriously.
collection1.First paragraph: Bill Baroni, Bridget Anne Kelly and David Wildstein waited for the first day of school.

collection1.Title: After 660, There Are Bigger Numbers in Sight
collection1.Caption: Alex Rodriguez hitting a homer at Fenway Park to tie Willie Mays for fourth place on the career home run list.

First paragraph.text: So Alex Rodriguez has now hit 660 home runs, as many as the great Willie Mays and a total surpassed by only Barry Bonds, Hank Aaron and Babe Ruth. Rodriguez was supposed to get a $6 million bonus from the Yankees for this, but now he may not. An arbitrator may well decide.

collection1.Title: On a Stage for High Drama, Alex Rodriguez Belts No. 660
collection1.Caption: The Yankees' Didi Gregorius scoring the tying run in the seventh inning at Fenway Park.

First paragraph.text: Fenway Park is the site of so much history for Alex Rodriguez, a polarizing figure in baseball but an especially antagonistic one here.

collection1.Title: New York Senate Leader and Son Are Arrested on Corruption Charges
collection1.Caption: State Senator Dean G. Skelos of Long Island and his son, Adam B. Skelos, arrived at the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building in Manhattan on Monday morning.
collection1.First paragraph: ALBANY — Dean G. Skelos, the leader of the New York State Senate, and his son were arrested on Monday by federal authorities on extortion, fraud and bribe solicitation charges, expanding the corruption investigation that has cast a renewed spotlight on Albany’s intractable corruption problem.

collection1.Title: Nepal Asks Foreign Rescuers to Leave as Hopes Fade
collection1.Caption: A Japanese rescue team in Sankhu, Nepal, on Friday. The death toll from the earthquake now exceeds 7,300. Some rescue workers said they would stay despite the government’s request.

First paragraph.text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The government of Nepal is asking foreign search-and-rescue teams to leave now that the likelihood of finding survivors buried by last month’s earthquake has largely passed, and a top Nepalese tourism official said Monday that no more climbers were likely to ascend Mount Everest this season.

collection1.Title: Marine Selected to Head Joint Chiefs
collection1.Caption: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., a former top commander in Afghanistan who now serves as commandant of the Marine Corps, is set to be nominated as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

collection1.Title: Bâtard Tops James Beard Award Winners
collection1.Caption: Drew Nieporent and Markus Glocker

First paragraph.text: On Monday night, for the first time, the annual James Beard Foundation gala — widely regarded as the Oscars ceremony of the food world — was held in Chicago rather than New York, recognizing Chicago’s dynamic and often cutting-edge food scene.

collection1.Title: Northern Ireland Unionists Hope for Power Gain in British Election
collection1.Caption: Sammy Wilson is seeking re-election to Parliament as a member of the Democratic Unionist Party, which is overwhelmingly Protestant and wants to keep Northern Ireland part of the United Kingdom.
collection1.First paragraph: CARRICKFERGUS, Northern Ireland — Ambling around this seaside town on a sunny afternoon, Sammy Wilson greeted smiling constituents like long-lost friends ahead of this week’s British general election.

collection1.Title: Lawmakers in France Move to Vastly Expand Surveillance
collection1.Caption: The lower house of the French parliament held a vote on Tuesday to adopt new surveillance rules.

collection1.Title: Donovan, Staten Island Prosecutor, Wins Congressional Seat Grimm Held
collection1.Caption: Daniel M. Donovan Jr., a Republican, declared victory at his election night party on Tuesday.
collection1.First paragraph: The Staten Island district attorney, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., whose office investigated the chokehold death of Eric Garner in a struggle with the police last year, easily won a special election for the House of Representatives on Tuesday, according to unofficial results.

collection1.Title: Rare Inning of Offense Holds Up for Mets Against Orioles
collection1.Caption: Mets left fielder Michael Cuddyer, left, catching a fly ball hit by Baltimore's Alejandro de Aza in the eighth inning as center fielder Juan Lagares got out of the way.

First paragraph.text: It had been 21 innings since any Mets player had experienced the rubbery sensation of home plate under his feet. But once they finally scored, in the fourth inning Tuesday night, it seemed to alleviate the angst that clung to the ball club like globs of pine tar throughout the weekend.

collection1.Title: N.S.A. Collection of Bulk Call Data Is Ruled Illegal
collection1.Caption: The entrance to a National Security Agency data collection center in Bluffdale, Utah.

First paragraph.text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court in New York ruled on Thursday that the once-secret National Security Agency program that is systematically collecting Americans’ phone records in bulk is illegal. The decision comes as a fight in Congress is intensifying over whether to end and replace the program, or to extend it without changes.

collection1.Title: How Britain’s Election Stumped Pollsters and the Betting Markets
collection1.Caption: Election workers heading to a polling station in Edinburgh on Wednesday afternoon ahead of Thursday's election.

First paragraph.text: UPDATE, May 7: A small movement in the political betting markets in recent hours makes David Cameron, the Conservative Party leader, the slight favorite to be returned as prime minister. Most British bookies give Mr. Cameron about a 51 to 52 percent chance.
